name: Amiga 600HD
coprocessor: ECS based chipset: 8375 Fat Agnus (memory controller and blitter), 8373 ECS Denise (video control chip), 8364R7 Paula (sound & I/O), Gayle (I/O, IDE interface)
ram: 1 MB Chip RAM, upgradeable to 6 MB max (2 MB chip RAM + 4 MB Fast RAM)
colors: Palette: 4096On screen: 4 in 1280 modes, 16 in 640 modes, 32 in 320 modes, 64 in EHB, 4096 in HAM
size: 14'' deep x 9.5'' wide x 3'' high / 6 lbs
ports: RS-232 serial port, Centronics parallel port, external disk interface, 2x RCA audio, PCMCIA/JEIDA card interface, IDE hard drive interface, composite video out, RF out, 2x Atari joystick/mouse ports
description: The Amiga 600HD is exactly the same as the standard A600 with the exception of a built-in 2.5" hard drive, hence the HD tag. A number of different packages were available with hard drive sizes ranging from 20 to 80 MB.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''<br> ''Now, go !''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Junya Kubota </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The TO7 from Thomson has everything needed to fill the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing pret-a-porter" <br><br> "Casio FX-702P : pocket Basic" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> (FUNNY) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>... from a promotional brochure</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says: <br><br><font color="#666666"> In other words, how to pop your office into a shoulder bag and then go out and about.<br> You see the Sharp PC7000 is no ordinary computer. Not only it is light, compact body packed with a much speed and power as most desk top computers, it's also very, very versatile... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is another french advert, not from CBS, but from an independant store "le jeu electronique". <br><br> Only the expansion module #3 was available in France and people had to buy a Colecovision if they wanted to have an Adam !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>As it's often the case with these promotional pictures, the whole scene sounds fake and so... unreal.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A step toward the future" <br><br> Hmmmm.....</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert shows all the tools a software developer could run on the MorthStar computers range (Horizon and Advantage) </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>We can see here the Palcom PX-7 with all its Pioneer extensions : the graphic tablet, the Laser Disc player, a joystick and even the TV is a Pioneer !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTWARE CATALOGUE</strong></font><br><blockquote>AcornSoft software catalogue for the Electron</blockquote>

item.description: MIDI Gold 500 |||by Golden Hawk Technology|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MIDI GOLD 500 </strong></font><br><strong>> by Golden Hawk Technology</strong><br><blockquote>This is a MIDI interface for the Amiga 500, 2000, or 3000... <br><br> It features :<br> - one MIDI In<br> - two MIDI Out<br> - one switchable Out/Thru<br> - one MIDI/Serial Switch<br> - one Out/Thru Switch<br></blockquote>
Memory expansion board||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMORY EXPANSION BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>2 / 4 / 6 / 8 MB expansion card here fitted with 2 MB.</blockquote>

Video board||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> VIDEO BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This board featured 2 MB of RAM and allowed the Amiga to be connected to a standard VGA monitor. All the video modes could be displayed, including the interlace one.</blockquote>
A570 CD-ROM||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> A570 CD-ROM</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Griffith for this picture</p></blockquote>

Hard Disk card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> HARD DISK CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>40 MB SCSI card from SUPRA CORP.<br><br> Additional SCSI devices could be connected in chain trough the back connector</blockquote>

emulator.name: WinFellow
emulator.description: Probably better at some games than UAE, but not as versatile.

emulator.name: AmigaSYS
emulator.description: AmigaSYS is a pre-installed full Amiga OS for WinUAE

emulator.name: Experimental UAE
emulator.description: Standard UAE enhanced with features from WinUAE.

emulator.name: MESS
emulator.description: MESS now emulates the Commodore Amiga

emulator.name: UAE
emulator.description: (Ubiquitous Amiga Emulator) for BeOS, Mac OS, Linux, NextStep, MSDOS, OS/2 and Win95/NT : Homepage.
